subject: Re: [junit] Parasoft JTest
msgSnippet: I think your analysis is correct. My experience shows that test-first is the most productive way to develop, especially when you take into account design
messageBody:
I think your analysis is correct. My experience shows that test-first is the
most productive way to develop, especially when you take into account design
quality and reduced debugging time. Truth is, even with the best intentions,
developers miss tests that can be created by such tools. My current thinking
is that I definately want to drive the main use-cases via test-first, but I
may let the tools create certain boundary condition tests for me - if I like
the code they generate.

Another tool maker to watch in this space is Agitar.

Regards,
David

-----------------
"Stedak" <sketcham at dsicdi dot com>

Hello!

Does anyone have any thoughts or experience with Parasoft's JTest
product? It is integrated with Eclipse to use JUnit.

On the upside I see that there is the knowledge that at least some
unit testing is being done to all code. Most of the developers here
do not test.

On the downside (my personal opinion), test-writing first or at least
at the same time as coding is much more effective than test-writing
after the fact. Code written without testing in mind is not very
testable. I don't see how JTest can help there although the code
standards module would seem to help.


For those who don't know, Parasoft's JTest is a tool to automatically
generate tests for your code. It does a number of other things also.
